positive.review: Game taught me how to play Poker. Never actually learned. Didn't have a father growing up. Went to the casino after playing Balatro and made a bunch of money. Donated said money to orphanage for kids without fathers‚Äîhopefully they'll learn how to play Poker some day too.

[b]Balatro[/b] is a roguelite deckbuilder pretending to be a pixel-art poker game.  I know everyone's at least heard of it at this point, [i]but[/i] I've 100%'d it 2.5 times on mobile and wrote this to figure out where my life went wrong.  

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
[b]Balatro[/b] eases you into madness: You start with a basic deck of 54 cards, score points on traditional poker hands, and earn money.   Spend that money on upgrades: joker cards that alter scoring, "tarot cards" that upgrade your deck, and "celestial" cards that increase point yields.  It seems so simple.  

And then it goes off the rails.

You're constantly unlocking new decks that behave in unique ways, new jokers that add crazy nuance and multipliers, new ways to score, etc.  "Spectral" cards tempt you to risk everything in exchange for massive gains.  New difficulties force you to level up faster.  Before you know it, you've spent an entire overnight flight trying to score a hand with five gold sevens of clubs, and have yet to sleep a wink.

[h3]What Works For Me[/h3]
‚úÖ I actually love the artwork.  It's so dumb and so simple, but some of the jokers are just‚Ä¶ the best.

‚úÖ I did not understand poker or poker hands before [b]Balatro[/b], but "Run Info" includes a simple visual guide that makes more sense than any video I've ever watched.

‚úÖ The card synergies!  The absolute insanity you can create with some Magicians and a Lucky Cat, or a King, a Mime, and a lot of chariots, red seals, and demonic deer!  

‚úÖ Players that stumble across particularly cool combinations can share "seeds" for others to enjoy too, or use their own seeds to conduct post-mortems on rounds that didn't quite work.   Seeded games do not count toward victories or achievements.  If you're still in relatively early game, this was in my most recent play-through and is hilariously OP; I have never hit the billions so quickly: DWDV2JTN

[h3]What Doesn't Work For Me[/h3]
üü• The Steam version is less intuitive than the mobile app (but does work well on Steamdeck).  On mobile, you drag and drop cards to buy, sell, use, etc.  On desktop, the cards sprout little tabs that you have to click to buy, sell, use, etc.  It's less tactile and a little more‚Ä¶ fiddly.

üü• The mobile version is a battery vampire.  I recently flew from the USA to Italy and back again, and despite having my Switch and a half-dozen reports to write, played [b]Balatro[/b] the entire time.  The battery pack that powered my husband's and my phones through a week-long blackout last year was fully depleted by the time I returned home. 

üü• Endless mode ramps up too quickly, especially on lower stakes.  You want to refine an interesting deck, but the game gives you a few extra antes before saying, "Okay, now score 300 million."   Well, fuck you too. 

üü• No one will read this review because this little indie game that the dev reportedly made for his friends has taken off like [i]Stardew Valley[/i].   I am so late to this party that it isn't even fashionable. 

[h3]Final Thoughts + Recommendation[/h3]
If you haven't played [b]Balatro[/b], or if you have but don't understand the hype (like me at first):  it starts off pretending to be poker, but it's not poker.  It is a tricky, RNG-driven roguelike with some [i]insanely[/i] cool engine-building and so much variety that you will never play the same game twice.  

In a weird way, I think it reminds me more of engine-building board games like [i]Terraforming Mars[/i], [i]Race for the Galaxy[/i], and [i]Splendor[/i] than any particular card game.  I love a good puzzle and building a good foundation, and that's what [b]Balatro[/b] is about.  It's also super easy to play in waiting rooms, lounges, in front of the TV, and so on.

If you enjoy [b]Balatro[/b], then I'd suggest checking out [i][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1404850/Luck_be_a_Landlord/?curator_clanid=45365863]Luck Be A Landlord[/url][/i], [i][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/646570/Slay_the_Spire/]Slay the Spire[/url][/i], and [i][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/3211750/Neongarten/?curator_clanid=45365863]Neongarten[/url][/i] for similar-but-different games.

Balatro is a deckbuilding roguelike where you score points by playing poker hands. Each round requires a higher score to pass, but you can improve your odds by gathering jokers with special abilities, changing and upgrading the cards in your deck, and leveling up your hands.

Each round basically has the same rules, although there are some minor variations depending on your deck and stake. Each deck has a bonus or variation on the regular rule set. You have to pass eight different bosses to win each deck. After each win, you unlock the next stake. There are nine different stakes, and each stake makes the game a little harder. Aside from playing regular rounds with normal decks, you can also play a number of challenge modes. Each challenge mode has a different set of starting conditions, and to pass it, you have to beat eight bosses just like in the regular mode.

Unlocking all of the different cards, completing all the challenges, earning all the achievements, and winning on gold stake (the highest difficulty) at least once with every deck is very difficult. Luck will affect every round you play, and that can be frustrating, especially when a really strong run ends early after some really abysmal luck. However, there is a lot of strategy to the game as well, and you can use it to manage your luck to make your chances of winning even better. It's also a lot of fun to try to come up with unusual combinations and strategies. 

I really enjoyed the pixelated, psychedelic art style and the hypnotic music. It gives the perfect atmosphere for sitting down to play one round of the game and accidentally getting up five hours later.

[b]KAMGUSTA's MINI REVIEW[/b]

The card rogue-lite everyone talks about. I understand why it's so popular, as almost everybody knows how to play cards and make a "double", a "three of a kind" or a "flush". Runs are also quite short and the high randomness makes all of them quite different. As a roguelike and/or deck-building game, it has big flaws: you aren't in full control of your deck (uncertainty and randomness are unavoidable) and the stacking of bonuses ([b]+[/b]chip, [b]+[/b]multi, [b]x[/b]multi) should have been clearer and better balanced. You can get to the point where a single card (a "high") scores more than a "royal flush", erasing all the fun of a card game. Game also lacks meta-progression, you just unlock more bonuses to be find on your runs. Runs are too short to build your deck or create long-term strategies - you are forced to just hope for good cards and push your luck. Best strategies focus only on gaining a lot of money to be able to reroll and trying to get (pray the RNG God) that couple uber bonuses.
For all those reasons, it's not the masterpiece some people talks about and I only recommend it for casual players (in that case, add +2 to the score). It is what it is: a casual, short-lenght, mobile game.

[h1]TLDR but longer down vote explanation at the bottom[/h1]
Crack rock gaming at its finest, with endless gameplay. Basically Poker/deck builder meets Vampire Survivors is the best way I can describe it. It sounds weird but hear me the fuck out. You first start the game with a regular poker hand, each round allows only so many played hands and redraws, if you dont beat the targeted score before your hand runs out you lose. The ‚Äúrouge lite‚Äù here is when you beat a round, you get money that you can spend on packs that can boost your cards or overall deck, and jokers which can modify/boost your entire build. The different type of builds you can set up each game is ridiculous and never gets old, as each run youre learning something new. Examples of builds are like a flush build, full house, 2 pair (typical poker), you try and build your entire deck so that you can support and boost these builds to be as powerful and dish out as much points as possible.

There are 8 antes to beat (endless after you beat it). Each ante has 3 rounds with the 3rd one being a boss with a random modifier, such as ‚Äúall face cards are disabled‚Äù. The higher you go up in rounds and antes the harder the game becomes bc the points to beat keeps increasing.....

[b]KAMGUSTA's MINI REVIEW[/b]

The card rogue-lite everyone talks about. I understand why it's so popular, as almost everybody knows how to play cards and make a "double", a "three of a kind" or a "flush". Runs are also quite short and the high randomness makes all of them quite different. As a roguelike and/or deck-building game, it has big flaws: you aren't in full control of your deck (uncertainty and randomness are unavoidable) and the stacking of bonuses ([b]+[/b]chip, [b]+[/b]multi, [b]x[/b]multi) should have been clearer and better balanced. You can get to the point where a single card (a "high") scores more than a "royal flush", erasing all the fun of a card game. Game also lacks meta-progression, you just unlock more bonuses to be find on your runs. Runs are too short to build your deck or create long-term strategies - you are forced to just hope for good cards and push your luck. Best strategies focus only on gaining a lot of money to be able to reroll and trying to get (pray the RNG God) that couple uber bonuses.
For all those reasons, it's not the masterpiece some people talks about and I only recommend it for casual players (in that case, add +2 to the score). It is what it is: a casual, short-lenght, mobile game.
